# Measures of central tendency {.section-title background-color="#c5b4e3"}

## Overview of descriptive statistics / summary measures

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
* Purpose of descriptive statistics?
* Purpose of summary measures?
    * Summarize a characteristic of a [distribution]{.underline} using a single number/score
        * Contrast to frequency distributions and graphs showing whole distribution
    * Advantage: efficient
    * Potential disadvantage: could obscure important information about the distribution
:::

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%"}
::: {.fragment fragment-index=2}
::: r-fit-text
> [**Measure of central tendency**]{style="color:#e93cac"}<br>single numbers used to convey<br>what is typical, common, usual, or<br>average in a distribution of scores
:::
:::
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
::: {.fragment fragment-index=3}
::: r-fit-text
> [**Measure of variability**]{style="color:#e93cac"}<br>single numbers used to convey the<br>diversity or heterogeneity in a<br>distribution of scores
:::
:::
:::

::::

## Measures of central tendency

<br>

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
#### Purpose

* *convey what is typical, common, usual, or average in a distribution of scores using a single number*
:::

<br>

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2}
#### Most common measures

* Mean
* Median
* Mode
:::

## Measure of central tendency: Mean

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="60%"}

<br>
<br>
<br>

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2 style="font-size: 3em"}

$$
\bar{X} = \frac{\Sigma  X_i}{N}
$$
:::
:::

::: {.column width="40%"}

<br>
<br>

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
::: r-fit-text
> [**Mean**]{style="color:#e93cac"}<br>The [arithmetic average]{.underline}<br>of the scores in a<br>distribution equal to<br>the sum of all scores<br>divided by the<br>number of scores<br>in the distribution
:::
:::
:::

::::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=3 data-id="box1" style="background: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0); border: 3px solid #e93cac; width: 90px; height: 85px; margin: 10px; position: absolute; top: 290px; left: 115px"}

:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=3 data-id="box2" style="background: #e93cac; border: 4px solid #690c48; border-radius: 15px; width: 210px; height: 100px; padding: 0px 0px 20px 10px; position: absolute; top: 430px; left: -50px"}
[***X Bar***]{.underline} refers to the mean of a variable called ***X***
:::


::: {.fragment fragment-index=4 data-id="box1" style="background: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0); border: 3px solid #1b8883; width: 70px; height: 80px; margin: 10px; position: absolute; top: 240px; left: 277px"}

:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=4 data-id="box2" style="background: #2ad2c9; border: 4px solid #1b8883; border-radius: 15px; width: 300px; height: 100px; padding: 0px 0px 20px 10px; position: absolute; top: 100px; left: 0px"}
[***Sigma***]{.underline}: summation sign meaning *add up everything that follows*
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=5 data-id="box1" style="background: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0); border: 3px solid #a68100; width: 72px; height: 80px; margin: 10px; position: absolute; top: 240px; left: 352px"}

:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=5 data-id="box2" style="background: #ffc700; border: 4px solid #a68100; border-radius: 15px; width: 300px; height: 75px; padding: 0px 0px 20px 10px; position: absolute; top: 120px; left: 322px"}
[***$X_i$***]{.underline} refers to the individual values of the variable ***X***
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=6 data-id="box1" style="background: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0); border: 3px solid #6e8e13; width: 72px; height: 80px; margin: 10px; position: absolute; top: 350px; left: 320px"}

:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=6 data-id="box2" style="background: #aadb1e; border: 4px solid #6e8e13; border-radius: 15px; width: 225px; height: 60px; padding: 0px 0px 20px 10px; position: absolute; bottom: 130px; left: 322px"}
[***$N$***]{.underline} = total number of cases
:::

## Example calculation

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
### Mean of age for a group of 10 individuals

Ages of sample members: 21, 34, 19, 20, 25, 41, 21, 23, 20, 18

:::

<br>

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2 style="font-size: 1.5em"}
#### [Calculating the mean]{.underline}

$$
\bar{X} = \frac{\Sigma X_i}{N} = \frac{X_1 + X_2 + X_3 + ... +X_n}{N}
$$

:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=3 style="font-size: 1.5em"}

$$
       = \frac{(21 + 34 + 19 + 20 + 25 + 41 + 21 + 23 + 20 + 18)}{10}
$$


:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=4 style="font-size: 1.5em"}

$$
       = \frac{242}{10} = 24.2 \text{ years}
$$

:::

#### Number of paper cups used per week by a sample of 67 college students

```{r}
cups
```

## Important properties of the mean

1. Appropriate only for interval-ratio variables
    * must be able to assume consistent units/values for mathematical operations
    
## Important properties of the mean

1. Appropriate only for interval-ratio variables
    * must be able to assume consistent units/values for mathematical operations
2. Mathematical balancing point of the distribution
    * magnitude of scores below the mean balance the magnitude of scores above the mean
    * Example: Annual salary of a sample of teachers ($1000’s)
    
## Important properties of the mean

1. Appropriate only for interval-ratio variables
    * must be able to assume consistent units/values for mathematical operations
2. Mathematical balancing point of the distribution
    * [magnitude of scores below the mean balance the magnitude of scores above the mean]{style="color:#e93cac"}
    * Example: Annual salary of a sample of teachers ($1000’s)

[![](images/mean_balance.png){fig-align="center" width="85%"}](https://brilliant.org/wiki/arithmetic-mean/)

---

[![](images/mean_balance.gif){fig-align="center" width="90%"}](https://bookdown.org/pkaldunn/Book/ComputeAverage.html)

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1 data-id="box2" style="background: #2ad2c9; border: 4px solid #1b8883; border-radius: 15px; width: 500px; height: 125px; padding: 0px 0px 20px 10px; position: absolute; bottom: 50px; left: 0px"}
Note that the numbers of cases on each side of the mean don’t match but their [relative magnitudes]{.underline} balance out (the mean remains the only balancing point)

:::
  
::: {.fragment fragment-index=2 data-id="box2" style="background: #ffc700; border: 4px solid #a68100; border-radius: 15px; width: 325px; height: 100px; padding: 0px 0px 20px 10px; position: absolute; bottom: 75px; right: 0px"}
The mean value does not always appear in the distribution
:::
 
--- 

#### Mathematical implications of the balancing-point property  

[![](images/mean_deviations.png){fig-align="left" width="80%"}](https://www.onlinemathlearning.com/mean-balance-point.html#google_vignette)

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1 data-id="box5" style="background: #c5b4e3; border: 4px solid #754cbc; border-radius: 15px; width: 300px; height: 515px; padding: 0px 0px 20px 20px; position: absolute; top: 100px; right: -75px"}
[**Deviation**]{style="color:#e93cac; font-size:2em"}<br>[*(from the mean)* <br>The difference<br>between an<br>individual<br>score/value<br>in the<br>distribution<br>and the mean of<br>the distribution]{style="font-size:1.5em"}
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1 data-id="box1" style="background: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0); border: 3px solid #e93cac; width: 290px; height: 25px; margin: 10px; position: absolute; top: 160px; left: 20px"}

:::

--- 

#### Mathematical implications of the balancing-point property 

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
* *The sum of the differences between the scores in a distribution and the mean of the distribution always equals zero.*

::: {style="font-size:1.9em"}
$$
\Sigma(X_i -\bar{X}) = 0
$$
:::
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2}
* *The sum of the [squared differences]{.underline} between the scores and the mean is smaller than the squared difference between the scores and any other point / value in the distribution.*
    * [*scores in any distribution are more clustered around the mean than around any other point*]{.fragment fragment-index=3 style="color:#e93cac"}
    *  [*in the absence of any other information, the mean is typically the best estimate of the score for any single case in the distribution*]{.fragment fragment-index=3 style="color:#e93cac"}

::: {style="font-size:1.9em"}
$$
\Sigma(X_i -\bar{X})^2 = minimum
$$
:::
:::

## Important properties of the mean

1. Appropriate only for interval-ratio variables
    * must be able to assume consistent units/values for mathematical operations
2. Mathematical balancing point of the distribution
    * magnitude of scores below the mean balance the magnitude of scores above the mean
    * Example: Annual salary of a sample of teachers ($1000’s)
3. Sensitive to extremes

---

#### Self-reported male heights (inches) 

```{r}
#| echo: false
#| fig-width: 9
#| fig-height: 6
#| fig-align: center

library(dslabs)
library(ggthemes)
library(ggrepel)

set.seed(725)
heights_subset <- heights |> filter(sex == "Male") |> slice_sample(n = 10, replace = FALSE)

heights_subset |> 
ggplot(aes(y = height, x = sex)) +
geom_point(position = position_jitter(seed = 725), size = 2) +
geom_hline(data = (heights_subset |> filter(sex == "Male") |> summarise(mean_height = mean(height), .by = sex)), aes(yintercept = mean_height), color = "#e93cac") +
geom_label_repel(data = (heights_subset |> filter(sex == "Male") |> summarise(mean_height = round(mean(height), 2), .by = sex)), aes(x = sex, y = mean_height, label = mean_height), color = "#e93cac") +
ylim(65, 91) +
labs(x = "Sex", y = "Height (inches)") +
theme_tufte(base_size = 18) + 
theme(legend.position = "none")
```

--- 

#### [Adding cases at the mean has no effect on the mean]{style="color:#e93cac"}

```{r}
#| echo: false
#| fig-width: 9
#| fig-height: 6
#| fig-align: center

set.seed(725)
mean_point <- tibble(sex = rep("Male", 1), height = mean(heights_subset$height))
heights1 <- bind_rows(mean_point, heights_subset)
heights_subset |> 
ggplot(aes(y = height, x = sex)) +
geom_point(position = position_jitter(seed = 725), size = 2) +
geom_point(data = mean_point, aes(y = height, x = sex), color = "#2ad2c9", size = 3, alpha = 0.75) +
geom_hline(data = (heights1 |> filter(sex == "Male") |> summarise(mean_height = mean(height), .by = sex)), aes(yintercept = mean_height), color = "#e93cac") +
ylim(65, 91) +
labs(x = "Sex", y = "Height (inches)") +
geom_label_repel(data = (heights1 |> filter(sex == "Male") |> summarise(mean_height = round(mean(height), 2), .by = sex)), aes(x = sex, y = mean_height, label = mean_height), color = "#e93cac") +
theme_tufte(base_size = 18) + 
theme(legend.position = "none")
```

## Important properties of the mean

1. Appropriate only for interval-ratio variables
    * must be able to assume consistent units/values for mathematical operations
2. Mathematical balancing point of the distribution
    * magnitude of scores below the mean balance the magnitude of scores above the mean
    * Example: Annual salary of a sample of teachers ($1000’s)
3. Sensitive to extremes
    * [questionable measure of what is [**typical**]{.underline} when the distribution contains extreme values (skewed distributions)]{style="color:#e93cac"}
    * [but the mean retains usefulness in many statistical techniques, even when the distribution is skewed]{style="color:#e93cac"}

## Measure of central tendency: Median

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
::: r-fit-text
> [**Median**]{style="color:#e93cac"}<br> • The score for the case in the exact middle of the distribution<br>• The point in the distribution at which half of cases fall above<br>that score and half of the cases fall below that score<br>• 50th percentile of the distribution
:::
:::

<br>

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2}
#### [Calculation]{.underline}

1. [**Order**]{.underline style="color:#e93cac"} cases by score (low-to-high or high-to-low)
2. Find the [**median case**]{.underline style="color:#e93cac"} (i.e., “median rank”)
    * [**MEDIAN CASE = $\frac{N + 1}{2}$**]{style="color:#e93cac"}
3. Identify the [score]{.underline style="color:#e93cac"} associated with the median case.

:::

## Example calculation [*(with an odd number of cases)*]{style="font-size:0.75em"}

<br>

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
#### Hours of TV watch for a group of inmates 

[4, 2, 7, 6, 0, 6, 1, 3, 5]{style="font-size:1.5em"}
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2}
#### Order the scores

[0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 6, 7]{style="font-size:1.5em"}
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=3}
#### Median case

[$\frac{N + 1}{2} = \frac{9 + 1}{2} =$]{style="font-size:1.5em"} [5th case]{style="color:#e93cac; font-size:1.5em"}
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=3 data-id="box1" style="background: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0); border: 3px solid #e93cac; width: 35px; height: 35px; margin: 10px; position: absolute; top: 270px; left: 130px"}

:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=4 data-id="box4" style="background: #ffc700; border: 4px solid #a68100; border-radius: 15px; width: 360px; height: 125px; padding: 0px 10px 20px 10px; position: absolute; top: 225px; left: 350px"}
Note that there are **four** cases with scores higher than the median and **four** with scores lower than the median
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=5 data-id="box3" style="background: #aadb1e; border: 4px solid #6e8e13; border-radius: 15px; width: 275px; height: 125px; padding: 0px 10px 20px 10px; position: absolute; bottom: 90px; left: 150px"}
The median for this distribution is the [score]{.underline} for the [case]{.underline} in the fifth ordered position
:::

## Example calculation [*(with an even number of cases)*]{style="font-size:0.75em"}

<br>

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
#### Hours of TV watch for a group of inmates 

[4, 2, 7, 6, 0, 6, 1, 3, 5, 0]{style="font-size:1.5em"}
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2}
#### Order the scores

[0, 0, 1, 2, 3,]{style="font-size:1.5em"}[|]{.fragment fragment-index=3 style="color:#e93cac; font-size:1.5em"}[4, 5, 6, 6, 7]{style="font-size:1.5em"}
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=3}
#### Median case

[$\frac{N + 1}{2} = \frac{10 + 1}{2} =$]{style="font-size:1.5em"} [5.5th case]{style="color:#e93cac; font-size:1.5em"}
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=3 data-id="box1" style="background: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0); border: 3px solid #e93cac; width: 77px; height: 35px; margin: 10px; position: absolute; top: 269px; left: 134px"}

:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=4 data-id="box4" style="background: #ffc700; border: 4px solid #a68100; border-radius: 15px; width: 360px; height: 125px; padding: 0px 10px 20px 10px; position: absolute; top: 225px; left: 400px"}
Note that there are **five** cases with scores higher than the median and **five** with scores lower than the median
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=5 data-id="box3" style="background: #aadb1e; border: 4px solid #6e8e13; border-radius: 15px; width: 475px; height: 200px; padding: 0px 10px 20px 10px; position: absolute; bottom: 0px; left: 150px"}
Median = score for the point halfway<br>between the 5th and 6th case. <br>
Score for 5th case = 3 <br>
Score for 6th case = 4 <br>
halfway between = [$\frac{3 + 4}{2} = 3.5$]{style="font-size:1.5em"}

::: 

---

### Calculating the median from a frequency distribution

::: {.smaller}
| Number of cups<br>(X)  | Frequency<br>(f)  | Percent<br>(%) | <br>Cf | <br>C%  |
|:--------:|:------:|:---:|---|---|
| 0 | 3 | 4.48 | 3 | 4.48 |

## Important properties of the median

1. Appropriate for interval-ratio or ordinal variables must be able to order scores

### Calculating the median for an ordinal variable

<br>

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="65%"}
::: {.smaller}
| Person number | How satisfied are you with your statistics course?  |
|:--------:|:------:|
| 2 | very dissatisfied |
| 6 | very dissatisfied |    
| 10 |  very dissatisfied |   
| 4 | somewhat dissatisfied |   
| 5 | somewhat dissatisfied |   
| 8 | somewhat dissatisfied |    
| 12 | somewhat dissatisfied |     
| 1 | somewhat satisfied |    
| 3 | somewhat satisfied | 
| 9 | somewhat satisfied |
| 11 | somewhat satisfied |  
| 7 | very satisfied | 

: {tbl-colwidths="[50,50]"}
:::
:::

::: {.column width="35%"}
Step 1: Put the cases in order by the score on the variable of interest
<br>
Step 2: Find the median case:<br>
$$
\frac{N + 1}{2}
$$
<br>
Median is the score associated with the median case

::: {.incremental}
* [Q: What do you do if the median case is between two different ordinal values?]{style="color:#e93cac"} <br>
* [A: Describe the median as between the categories]{style="color:#4b2e83"}

:::
:::

::::

## Important properties of the median

1. Appropriate for interval-ratio or ordinal variables must be able to order scores
2. In comparison to the mean, the median is less affected by extreme scores 
    * but not completely unaffected
    * [**number of scores**]{style="color:#e93cac"}, not their magnitude, at different parts of the distribution [**is what matters**]{style="color:#e93cac"}…

---

#### Self-reported male heights (inches) 

```{r}
#| echo: false
#| fig-width: 9
#| fig-height: 6
#| fig-align: center

set.seed(725)
heights_subset <- heights |> filter(sex == "Male") |> slice_sample(n = 10, replace = FALSE)

heights_subset |> 
ggplot(aes(y = height, x = sex)) +
geom_point(size = 2) +
geom_hline(data = (heights_subset |> filter(sex == "Male") |> summarise(median_height = median(height), .by = sex)), aes(yintercept = median_height), color = "#e93cac", linetype = 2) +
geom_label_repel(data = (heights_subset |> filter(sex == "Male") |> summarise(median_height = round(median(height), 2), .by = sex)), aes(x = sex, y = median_height, label = median_height), color = "#e93cac") +
ylim(65, 91) +
labs(x = "Sex", y = "Height (inches)") +
theme_tufte(base_size = 18) + 
theme(legend.position = "none")
```

## Measure of central tendency: Mode

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
::: r-fit-text
> [**Mode**]{style="color:#e93cac"}<br> The most frequently occurring score in the distribution

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2}
* most in line with the [*most typical*]{.underline} meaning of central tendency
* Single score most likely to occur = most likely to be selected at random

## Important properties of the mode

::: {.incremental}
1. Appropriate for any level of measurement
2. A distribution may have multiple modes
    * bimodal, trimodal, etc.
    * mode less useful in these situations (no longer a single number to convey what is typical)
:::

## Choosing a measure of central tendency

#### 3 criteria: 

::: {.incremental}
1. [Level of measurement]{style="background:#6e8e13"}
    * Limits options for central tendency
        * Interval variable: mode, median, or mean
        * Ordinal variable: mode or median
        * Nominal variable: mode
2. [Amount of information incorporated into the measure]{style="background:#1b8883"}
    * Mean uses most information, median the second most
3. [Shape of the distribution]{style="background:#a68100"}
    * Mean can give misleading picture of what is *common* or *typical* in a skewed distribution
    * But the mean is so commonly understood that, [with a skewed distribution]{.underline}, we often use **BOTH** the [median]{style="color:#e93cac"} and [mean]{style="color:#e93cac"}
:::

    * Latino concentration: low (<15%), medium (15 to 40%), high (>40%)
    * Percent Latino: (Latino Population/Total Population)*100
* Measure of number of dollars donated to charity
* Measure of number of dollars donated to charity with central tendency scores:
  * Mode = $0
  * Median = $150
  * Mean = $1,200
  
## Practice 

#### Choose the “best” measure of central tendency for the following

* Measure of job satisfaction using a Likert scale
    * very satisfied, somewhat satisfied, neutral, somewhat dissatisfied,  very dissatisfied
  
<br>  

::: {.fragment}
#### Criteria
:::

2. [**Median**]{style="color:#1b8883"} uses [more information]{style="color:#1b8883"} than the [**mode**]{style="color:#1b8883"}
3. [**Shape**]{style="color:#a68100"} of the distribution [**not relevant**]{style="color:#a68100"} since [**median not greatly affected**]{style="color:#a68100"}

# Break! {.section-title background-color="#2ad2c9"}

# Measures of variability {.section-title background-color="#c5b4e3"}

## Overview of variability

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="45%"}

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2}
* Synonyms: diversity, heterogeneity, dispersion
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=3}
* Common measures
    * [Range]{style="color:#e93cac"}
    * [Interquartile range (IQR)]{style="color:#e93cac"}
    * [Variance and Standard Deviation]{style="color:#e93cac"}
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=4}
* Most measures of variability appropriate for interval-level variables only
    * [Range can be used for ordinal variables]{style="color:#4b2e83"}
    * [For nominal variables, describe diversity by examining frequencies in each category]{style="color:#4b2e83"}
:::

:::

::: {.column width="55%"}

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
::: r-fit-text
> [Measure of variability]{style="color:#e93cac"}<br>single numbers used<br>to convey the<br>diversity or<br>heterogeneity<br>in a distribution<br>of scores.
:::
:::
:::

::::

## Range

* Difference between the highest and lowest value appearing in the distribution

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1 style="font-size:1.5em;"}
$$
Range = X_{max} - X_{min}
$$
:::

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%"}
::: {.fragment fragment-index=2}
```{r}
#| echo: false
#| fig-height: 4
#| fig-width: 5
#| fig-align: center
score1 <- tibble(Score = 0:20, Frequency = c(23, 23, 14, 25, 21, 25, 26, 27, 14, 8, 17, 23, 25, 27, 22, 23, 18, 25, 21, 25, 26))
ggplot(score1, aes(x = Score, y = Frequency)) + 
geom_col() +
theme_tufte(base_size = 12) 
```
:::
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
::: {.fragment fragment-index=3}
```{r}
#| echo: false
#| fig-height: 4
#| fig-width: 5
#| fig-align: center
score2 <- tibble(Score = 0:20, Frequency = c(2, 1, 0, 0, 0, 1, 1, 5, 5, 15, 10, 15, 20, 11, 6, 7, 3, 0, 0, 1, 2))
ggplot(score2, aes(x = Score, y = Frequency)) + 
geom_col() +
theme_tufte(base_size = 12) 
```
:::
:::

::::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=4 data-id="box3" style="background: #aadb1e; border: 4px solid #6e8e13; border-radius: 15px; width: 125px; height: 35px; padding: 0px 10px 20px 10px; position: absolute; top: 225px; right: 175px"}
$20 - 0 = 20$
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=4 data-id="box4" style="background: #ffc700; border: 4px solid #a68100; border-radius: 15px; width: 125px; height: 35px; padding: 0px 10px 20px 10px; position: absolute; top: 225px; left: 175px"}
$20 - 0 = 20$
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=5 data-id="box2" style="background: #2ad2c9; border: 4px solid #1b8883; border-radius: 15px; width: 200px; height: 130px; padding: 0px 0px 10px 10px; position: absolute; top: 150px; left: -75px; font-size:0.85em"}
Same range, but are the two distributions equally diverse?
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=5 data-id="box2" style="background: #2ad2c9; border: 4px solid #1b8883; border-radius: 15px; width: 300px; height: 125px; padding: 0px 0px 10px 10px; position: absolute; bottom: 0px; right: 350px; font-size:0.85em"}
Problem with the range: ignores lots of information so can be a misleading measure of diversity.
:::

## Interquartile Range (IQR)

* Difference between the 75th and 25th percentiles in the distribution

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1 style="font-size:1.5em;"}
$$
IQR = X_{75th} - X_{25th}
$$
:::

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%"}

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2}
* First quartile: 25th percentile
    * 25% of the observations are smaller than the 1st quartile, 75% are larger
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=3}
* Second quartile: 50th percentile, the median
    * 50% of the observations are smaller, 50% larger

:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=4}
* Third quartile: 75th percentile
    * 75% of the observations are smaller than the 3rd quartile, 25% are larger
:::

:::

::: {.column width="50%"}

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
::: r-fit-text
> [**Quartiles**]{style="color:#e93cac"}<br>Sections of the<br>distribution in which<br>¼ of the observations/<br>cases are located
:::
:::
:::

::::

## How to calculate the quartiles

::: incremental
1. Arrange the observations in increasing order and locate the median, M.
2. The [**first quartile Q1**]{style="color:#2ad2c9"} is the median (midpoint) of the observations located to the left of the median in the ordered list.
3. The [**third quartile Q3**]{style="color:#e93cac"} is the median (midpoint) of the observations located to the right of the median in the ordered list.
:::

## IQR example 1

```{r}
#| echo: false
#| fig-height: 4
#| fig-width: 5
#| fig-align: center
score1_full <- tibble(Score = rep(score1$Score, times = score1$Frequency))
ggplot(score1, aes(x = Score, y = Frequency)) + 
geom_col() +
theme_tufte(base_size = 10) 
```

## IQR example 1 ([15.75]{style="color:#2ad2c9"}  - [5]{style="color:#e93cac"}  = 10)

```{r}
#| echo: false
#| fig-height: 4
#| fig-width: 5
#| fig-align: center
ggplot(score1, aes(x = Score, y = Frequency)) + 
geom_col() +
geom_vline(data = score1_full, aes(xintercept = quantile(Score, probs = 0.25)), size = 1, color = "#2ad2c9", linetype = 2) +
theme_tufte(base_size = 10) 
```

::: {data-id="box2" style="background: #2ad2c9; border: 4px solid #1b8883; border-radius: 15px; width: 340px; height: 35px; padding: 0px 0px 20px 20px; position: absolute; bottom: -25px; left: 75px"}
Score at 25th percentile = 5
:::

## IQR example 1 ([15.75]{style="color:#2ad2c9"}  - [5]{style="color:#e93cac"}  = 10)

```{r}
#| echo: false
#| fig-height: 4
#| fig-width: 5
#| fig-align: center
ggplot(score1, aes(x = Score, y = Frequency)) + 
geom_col() +
geom_vline(data = score1_full, aes(xintercept = quantile(Score, probs = 0.25)), size = 1, color = "#2ad2c9", linetype = 2) +
geom_vline(data = score1_full, aes(xintercept = quantile(Score, probs = 0.75)), size = 1, color = "#e93cac", linetype = 2) +
theme_tufte(base_size = 10) 
```

## What’s the use of the IQR?

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
* In what situations would the IQR be helpful?
    * What kinds of problems does it solve?
* How much information does the IQR really consider?
:::

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="35%"}
::: {.fragment fragment-index=3}

::: r-fit-text
> [**Outliers**]{style="color:#e93cac"}<br>An extremely<br>high value<br>or extremely<br>low value<br>in a distribution<br>(that may skew<br>the results of our<br>statistical analysis)
:::
:::
:::

::: {.column width="65%"}
::: {.fragment fragment-index=2}
* Measure of spread: Are the individuals in our data set very different on this variable or not?
* Useful for finding possible [**outliers**]{.underline}
    * Rule of thumb for identifying outliers = [call an observation an outlier if it falls more than 1.5 × IQR above the third quartile or below the first quartile]{style="color:#e93cac"}
:::
:::

::::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=3 style="width: 55%; position: absolute; bottom: -25px; right: 0px"}
[![](images/outliers.png){width="80%"}](https://tinystats.github.io/teacups-giraffes-and-statistics/04_variance.html)
:::

## Variance

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
* Closely related measures of variability for interval-level variables
    * Takes into consideration [all scores]{.underline} in the distribution
    * Indicates the spread of cases [from the mean]{.underline}
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2}
::: r-fit-text
> [**Variance**]{style="color:#e93cac"}<br>A measure of variability for interval level variables equal to the <br> [**average of the squared deviations from the mean**]{.underline}
:::
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=3}
::: r-fit-text
> [**Standard deviation**]{style="color:#e93cac"}<br>A measure of variability for interval level variables equal to the<br>[**square root of the variance**]{.underline}
:::
:::

## Variance and standard deviation equations 

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2}
* Variance: *A measure of variability for interval level variables equal to the [**average of the squared deviations from the mean**]{style="color:#e93cac"}*
:::

::: {style="font-size:1.5em"}
$$
s_x^2 = \frac{\Sigma(X_i - \bar{X})^2}{n - 1}
$$
:::


::: {.fragment fragment-index=2}
* Standard deviation: *A measure of variability for interval level variables equal to the [**square root of the variance**]{style="color:#e93cac"}*
:::

::: {style="font-size:1.5em"}
$$
s_x = \sqrt{\frac{\Sigma(X_i - \bar{X})^2}{n - 1}}
$$
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=3 data-id="box1" style="background: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0); border: 3px solid #e93cac; width: 60px; height: 50px; margin: 10px; position: absolute; top: 223px; left: 360px"}

:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=3 data-id="box2" style="background: #e93cac; border: 4px solid #690c48; border-radius: 15px; width: 210px; height: 70px; padding: 0px 0px 20px 10px; position: absolute; top: 170px; left: 100px"}
Variance for a variable called $X$
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=5 data-id="box1" style="background: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0); border: 3px solid #754cbc; width: 55px; height: 50px; margin: 10px; position: absolute; bottom: 115px; left: 340px"}

:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=5 data-id="box5" style="background: #c5b4e3; border: 4px solid #754cbc; border-radius: 15px; width: 200px; height: 125px; padding: 0px 0px 20px 10px; position: absolute; bottom: 100px; left: 85px"}
Sum of squared deviations from the mean for each score
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=4 data-id="box1" style="background: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0); border: 3px solid #6e8e13; width: 210px; height: 115px; margin: 10px; position: absolute; top: 185px; left: 450px"}

:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=4 data-id="box3" style="background: #aadb1e; border: 4px solid #6e8e13; border-radius: 15px; width: 200px; height: 100px; padding: 0px 10px 20px 10px; position: absolute; top: 170px; right: 70px"}
Standard deviation for a variable called $X$
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=6 data-id="box1" style="background: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0); border: 3px solid #ffc700; width: 250px; height: 150px; margin: 10px; position: absolute; bottom: 65px; left: 435px"}

:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=6 data-id="box4" style="background: #ffc700; border: 4px solid #a68100; border-radius: 15px; width: 275px; height: 240px; padding: 0px 10px 20px 10px; position: absolute; bottom: 0px; right: -25px"}
**Funkiness alert**: Some texts show the denominator as $n$. Here we are presuming that we will ultimately calculate $s_x$ in the context of inference.
:::

## Calculating the variance & standard deviation

#### Six steps

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
1. Calculate the mean of the distribution
2. Subtract the mean from each score to get the deviation
3. Square each deviation
4. Sum the squared deviations
5. Divide the sum by n-1 to get the variance
6. Take the square root of the variance to get the standard deviation
:::

<br>

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2}
#### Example: Quiz scores for 8 students:
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2 style="font-size:1.5em;"}
43, 50, 75, 77, 80, 82, 85, 92
:::

---

### STEP 1

#### [Calculate the mean of the distribution]{style="color:#e93cac;"}

| Student | Quiz Score (X)  | $X - \bar{X}$ | $(X - \bar{X})^2$ |
|:--------:|:------:|:------:|:------:|
| a | 43 |  |   |
| b | 50 |  |   |
| c | 75 |  |   |
| d | 77 |  |   |   
| e | 80 |  |   |   
| f | 82 |  |   |
| g | 85 |  |   |    
| h | 92 |  |   |   
| **SUM** | **584** |   |   | 
| **MEAN** | **73** |   |   | 


: {tbl-colwidths="[25, 25, 25, 25]"}

---

### STEP 1

#### [Calculate the mean of the distribution]{style="color:#e93cac"}

| Student | Quiz Score (X)  | $X - \bar{X}$ | $(X - \bar{X})^2$ |
|:--------:|:------:|:------:|:------:|
| a | 43 |  |   |
| b | 50 |  |   |
| c | 75 |  |   |
| d | 77 |  |   |   
| e | 80 |  |   |   
| f | 82 |  |   |
| g | 85 |  |   |    
| h | 92 |  |   |   
| **SUM** | **584** |  |  |
| **MEAN** | [**73** ]{style="color:#e93cac;"} |   |   | 

: {tbl-colwidths="[25, 25, 25, 25]"}
  
::: {data-id="box2" style="background: #e93cac; border: 4px solid #690c48; border-radius: 15px; width: 325px; height: 100px; padding: 0px 0px 20px 10px; position: absolute; bottom: 75px; right: 175px; font-size:1.25em;"}
$$
\bar{X} = \frac{\Sigma X_i}{n} = \frac{584}{8} = 73
$$
:::

---

### STEP 2

#### [Subtract the mean from each score to get the *deviation* (*$X_i - \bar{X}$)*]{style="color:#e93cac;"}

| Student | Quiz Score (X)  | $X - \bar{X}$ | $(X - \bar{X})^2$ |
|:--------:|:------:|:------:|:------:|
| [a]{style="color:#e93cac;"} | [43]{style="color:#e93cac;"} | [-30]{style="color:#e93cac;"} |   |
| b | 50 | -23 |   |
| c | 75 | 2 |   |
| d | 77 | 4 |   |   
| e | 80 | 7 |   |   
| f | 82 | 9 |   |
| g | 85 | 12 |   |    
| h | 92 | 19 |   |   
| **SUM** | **584** | **0**  |   | 
| **MEAN** | [**73**]{style="color:#e93cac;"} |   |   | 

: {tbl-colwidths="[25, 25, 25, 25]"}
  
::: {data-id="box2" style="background: #e93cac; border: 4px solid #690c48; border-radius: 15px; width: 325px; height: 250px; padding: 0px 0px 20px 10px; position: absolute; top: 175px; right: 0px;"}
[Student a:]{.underline} <br>
<br>
$Deviation = 43 - 73 = -30$ <br>
<br>
Student a's score on the quiz is 30 points below the average
:::

---

### STEP 2

#### [Subtract the mean from each score to get the *deviation* (*$X_i - \bar{X}$)*]{style="color:#e93cac;"}

| Student | Quiz Score (X)  | $X - \bar{X}$ | $(X - \bar{X})^2$ |
|:--------:|:------:|:------:|:------:|
| [a]{style="color:#e93cac;"} | [43]{style="color:#e93cac;"} | [-30]{style="color:#e93cac;"} |   |
| b | 50 | -23 |   |
| c | 75 | 2 |   |
| d | 77 | 4 |   |   
| e | 80 | 7 |   |   
| f | 82 | 9 |   |
| g | 85 | 12 |   |    
| h | 92 | 19 |   |   
| **SUM** | **584** | [**0**]{style="color:#1b8883;"}  |   | 
| **MEAN** | [**73**]{style="color:#e93cac;"} |   |   | 

: {tbl-colwidths="[25, 25, 25, 25]"}
  
::: {data-id="box2" style="background: #e93cac; border: 4px solid #690c48; border-radius: 15px; width: 325px; height: 250px; padding: 0px 0px 20px 10px; position: absolute; top: 175px; right: 0px;"}
[Student a:]{.underline} <br>
<br>
$Deviation = 43 - 73 = -30$ <br>
<br>

:::

::: {data-id="box2" style="background: #2ad2c9; border: 4px solid #1b8883; border-radius: 15px; width: 225px; height: 50px; padding: 0px 0px 10px 10px; position: absolute; bottom: 135px; right: 125px;"}
Why is the sum 0?
:::

---

### STEP 3

#### [Square all of the deviations from the mean]{style="color:#e93cac;"}

| Student | Quiz Score (X)  | $X - \bar{X}$ | [$(X - \bar{X})^2$]{style="color:#e93cac;"} |
|:--------:|:------:|:------:|:------:|
| a | 43 | -30 | 900 |
| b | 50 | -23 | 529  |
| c | 75 | 2 | 4 |
| d | 77 | 4 | 16 |   
| e | 80 | 7 | 49 |   
| f | 82 | 9 | 81 |
| g | 85 | 12 | 144 |    
| h | 92 | 19 | 361 |   
| **SUM** | **584** | **0**  |  | 
| **MEAN** | **73** |   |   | 

: {tbl-colwidths="[25, 25, 25, 25]"}
  
::: {.fragment fragment-index=1 data-id="box2" style="background: #e93cac; border: 4px solid #690c48; border-radius: 15px; width: 375px; height: 150px; padding: 0px 0px 10px 20px; position: absolute; top: 175px; right: 300px;"}
Squaring the deviations is just a way to make sure that positive and negative deviations don't cancel each other out
:::

::: {.aside .fragment fragment-index=1}
You can read more about the reason we use squared deviations [here](https://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/118/why-square-the-difference-instead-of-taking-the-absolute-value-in-standard-devia). 
:::

### STEP 4

#### [Sum all of the squared deviations]{style="color:#e93cac;"}

| Student | Quiz Score (X)  | $X - \bar{X}$ | $(X - \bar{X})^2$ |
|:--------:|:------:|:------:|:------:|
| a | 43 | -30 | 900 |
| b | 50 | -23 | 529  |
| c | 75 | 2 | 4 |
| d | 77 | 4 | 16 |   
| e | 80 | 7 | 49 |   
| f | 82 | 9 | 81 |
| g | 85 | 12 | 144 |    
| h | 92 | 19 | 361 |   
| **SUM** | **584** | **0**  | [**2084**]{style="color:#e93cac;"} | 
| **MEAN** | **73** |   |   | 

: {tbl-colwidths="[25, 25, 25, 25]"}
  
::: {.fragment fragment-index=1 data-id="box2" style="background: #e93cac; border: 4px solid #690c48; border-radius: 15px; width: 375px; height: 150px; padding: 0px 0px 10px 20px; position: absolute; top: 175px; right: 300px;"}
Squaring the deviations is just a way to make sure that positive and negative deviations don't cancel each other out
:::

::: {.aside .fragment fragment-index=1}
You can read more about the reason we use squared deviations [here](https://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/118/why-square-the-difference-instead-of-taking-the-absolute-value-in-standard-devia). 
:::

### STEP 5

#### [Divide the sum by $n-1$ to get the variance]{style="color:#e93cac;"}

| Student | Quiz Score (X)  | $X - \bar{X}$ | $(X - \bar{X})^2$ |
|:--------:|:------:|:------:|:------:|
| a | 43 | -30 | 900 |
| b | 50 | -23 | 529  |
| c | 75 | 2 | 4 |
| d | 77 | 4 | 16 |   
| e | 80 | 7 | 49 |   
| f | 82 | 9 | 81 |
| g | 85 | 12 | 144 |    
| h | 92 | 19 | 361 |   
| **SUM** | **584** | **0**  | [**2084**]{style="color:#e93cac;"} | 
| **MEAN** | **73** |   |   | 

: {tbl-colwidths="[25, 25, 25, 25]"}
  
::: {data-id="box2" style="background: #e93cac; border: 4px solid #690c48; border-radius: 15px; width: 500px; height: 110px; padding: 0px 0px 20px 10px; position: absolute; bottom: 100px; left: 200px; font-size:1.25em;"}
$$
s_x^2 = \frac{\Sigma(X_i - \bar{X})^2}{n - 1} = \frac{2084}{7} = 297.71
$$
:::

::: {.aside}
Variance = average [squared]{.underline} deviation from the mean
:::

### STEP 6

#### [Take the square root of the variance to get the [standard deviation]{.underline}]{style="color:#e93cac;"}

| Student | Quiz Score (X)  | $X - \bar{X}$ | $(X - \bar{X})^2$ |
|:--------:|:------:|:------:|:------:|
| a | 43 | -30 | 900 |
| b | 50 | -23 | 529  |
| c | 75 | 2 | 4 |
| d | 77 | 4 | 16 |   
| e | 80 | 7 | 49 |

| g | 85 | 12 | 144 |

: {tbl-colwidths="[25, 25, 25, 25]"}

$$
s_x = \sqrt{\frac{\Sigma(X_i - \bar{X})^2}{n - 1}}
$$
$$
= \sqrt{297.71}
$$
$$
= 17.25
$$
:::

## Interpreting the standard deviation

::: {.incremental}
* [ROUGHLY]{.underline} equal to the [average deviation]{.underline} of scores in the distribution from the mean of the distribution
    * squaring and square-rooting leads to some *slippage*
* Minimum value = 0 = no variation in scores
* Useful for comparing the level of diversity or heterogeneity of two or more different distributions
    * Example: Quiz scores from 3 classes:
        * Class 1: Mean = 75, standard deviation = 5
        * Class 2: Mean = 75, standard deviation = 15
        * Class 3: Mean = 75, standard deviation = 0
* Important as the unit of measurement to determine how unusual or extreme a particular score is
    * Question: In which class is a score of 90 most unusual?
    * Question: In which class is a score of 90 more typical?
* Useful in combination with the normal curve
:::
